greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write 2*n - 1 = 2*p + q with p, q, phi(p+1) - 1 and phi(p+1) + 1 all prime, where phi(.) is Euler's totient function.
comment: (ii) Any even number greater than 4 can be written as p + q with p, q, phi(p+2) - 1 and phi(p+2) + 1 all prime.
Part (i) implies both Lemoine's conjecture (cf. A046927) and the twin prime conjecture, while part (ii) unifies Goldbach's conjecture and the twin prime conjecture.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, Unification of Goldbach's conjecture and the twin prime conjecture, a message to Number Theory List, Jan. 29, 2014.
example: a(9) = 1 since 2*9 - 1 = 2*7 + 3 with 7, 3, phi(7+1) - 1 = 3 and phi(7+1) + 1 = 5 all prime.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Feb 04 2014
